dialogues.text: I’ve tried that. She won't go. Windows in the office look out on a larger warehouse, ful racks of clothing, mannequins, and bins of coat hangers. Paul flicks through pages on a web browser as he stands a his desk, switching the phone to the other ear.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rebecca? She’s her own train wreck. And I see her maybe once a year. I can’t expect her to help us. Paul listens to the person on the other end of the call. Nods along as if he agrees with them. All the while, he absently toys with his wedding band on ring finger with his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, okay. A light clicks ON in the warehouse, and a young man named KEITH (20s) crosses through an aisle to the office door. He knocks and enters, holding a tablet--

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Okay, so-- (notices phone) Oop. Paul covers the mouthpiece with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: PAUL

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)

As Paul shuts down the applications on his computer, he g it down to the DESKTOP WALLPAPER IMAGE: Paul, SOPHIE (40s, smiling, hair that hints Warning: Mani and MARTIN (8, somber, looking past camera).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The square MOTION-ACTIVATED SENSOR tucked high in a corne clicks, its red detection-light winking off-- And the warehouse lights sputter to life again. Paul locks the back office. dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Keith? You still here? Silence. Paul stands on tiptoes to peer over the racks. No movement. The lights click OFF. Paul turns around, staring up at the motion activator.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sotto) Oh, come on. He waves his arm at it. Trying to trigger it. Behind him, at the end of the aisle, a DARK SILHOUETTE s out from between the racks of clothes. It seems tall. With long, unkempt hair that disguises the shape of its head and neck. And oddly, it doesn’t seem to be wearing clothes. Its sha is too smooth; too raw. Paul isn’t aware of it. THE MOTION SENSOR still doesn’t wink on. In the dark, its small red ‘detection’ light glows wanly. PAUL waves with bigger gestures... And the SILHOUETTE advances for him... Slowly at first, then picking up speed, then THE LIGHTS c on again, sputtering to life-- And there is no one else in the aisle besides Paul. Paul turns around-- And notices the hanging dresses a few feet from him swayi as if brushed by someone’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? No answer. Paul hurries for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul rolls the metal security gate down on the front entr to the clothing storefront. Locks the gate with his keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mall is quiet as a museum at night. It must be October, because Halloween decorations are out Ghosts and bats hanging on fishing wire. Scarecrows amid hay bales. Witches with pointy hats posed over kiosks. The whole place is dimly lit, mostly shut down. It’s cle Paul was working past closing time. No other shops are li Not even the hallway. Just the shelf lighting under the planters, and the occasional kiosk lights, showcasing some ad or mall map. Paul makes his way for the parking garage. As he passes a kiosk-- His SHADOW is cast upon the wall beside him. Advancing as continues past, stretching at a slanted angle. And a SECOND shadow advances just behind it. That same silhouette. Paul catches sight of it, and turns-- Nothing’s there. Nothing to make that shadow on the wall. He looks again at the wall-- It’s just his own shadow, and a very faint secondary one could be another shadow of his cast by a separate lamp. Paul’s phone RINGS. Startles the hell out of him. Nerves rattled, he checks the screen: “Home”

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (answers) Hello? (then) Hey, kiddo. I’m coming home now. Promise I‘’ll be there soon. Paul picks up the pace as he talks to his son.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) How’s mom doing tonight? (beat) Yeah? Better? Paul reaches the doors to the parking garage. One last look back: All is quiet. All is still.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Well I’m on my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the sliding doors open for Paul, a sodium-vapor lamp awakens, saturating the structure in a dirty amber tint. This garage isn’t a typical parking building. Someone tri to make it look “arty” with its concrete pilings, turning sharp corners into rounded ends, and elongating support b in logarithmic curves. But at night, the effect is eerie: It looks like you’re inside the ribcage of an enormous Giger-esque monster. Paul’s Toyota sedan is one of maybe three cars still park at this hour, a hundred feet from the doors. Paul marches for it, keys in one hand, phone in the other It is a long and tense walk. Paul keeps looking around fo signs of other people. His footsteps echo in the cavernous space. Paul gets to the Toyota, unlocking it with his key fob. Behind him, the sodium-vapor security light goes out, drenching the garage in darkness. Paul opens the driver's door, grateful for the car’s inte light which casts a downward glow on the area around it. He hears something: The sound of the building doors slidi Paul turns around, unnerved, because the amber security l did not wink on this time. At the glass doors to the mall: THE SILHOUETTE.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Who’s there? Silence. Paul leans in, the Toyota squeaking from the weight of hi body. He grabs a flashlight from his glovebox and stands again at the door. His fight-or-flight feelings battle hi stubborn need to not be bullied or pranked. He clicks on the flashlight’s bright, narrow beam. Shines right at the silhouette-- And it’s GONE. Like the light erased it from existence. Paul frowns. Confused. Bordering on panic. He lowers the of light, shining it on his feet-- And the silhouette has returned. Thirty feet closer. Paul lifts the light again. Directing it at the shadow-fo Again: Just light and garage wall in the distance. Beat. Paul lowers the flashlight beam-- And the silhouette is A DOZEN FEET AWAY. Paul jumps-- emits a partial curse word, and brings that light beam up reflexively. Protectively. Once again, nothing. But now, he hears it. Feet scuffling on the ground. Hurrying in some direction. Paul sweeps the beam left and right, in search of it. Nothing. Then: a slight sound behind him. The Toyota squeaking as something leans against it. Paul looks down. A shadow is cast from the car’s interior light: Something is standing right behind him. Paul starts to whirl around but-- The flashlight shines in our eyes as some hint of a HAND grabs his wrist and-- Another dark-as-ink CLAWED HAND reaches around and covers mouth and-- THE FLASHLIGHT crashes to the ground, breaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. Then the sodium-vapor lamp awakens again, revea Paul’s mangled body on the ground by his car.

dialogues.text: INT. BEDROOM —- NIGHT More posters of metal bands, artwork from cult comic book Crappy furniture. A single bed with disheveled sheets, currently occupied by a young COUPLE: REBECCA (20s) and BRET (20s) share a cigarette, staring a the ceiling. As if to cover over an older tattoo or birthmark. She looks at her right arm, currently bare. The inside of this arm is peppered with neat rows of shor scars. Too neat to be accidental. dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (0.S.)

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: BRET

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: BRET

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN

dialogues.text: Go back to bed, sweetie. Only ones wandering the halls at this hour should be grown-ups. Sophie stares tiredly at her son. Gives him a slight nod “Go on, now.” Martin turns around, takes two steps back for his room...

dialogues.text: (sotto) I know. But he means well. Martin looks back, over his shoulder. Sophie’s returned to looking into the closet... He hurries back down the hall, for his door-- INT. MARTIN’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS --rushing in and shutting the door behind him. Locking it Climbing into bed. Tense, expectant, he stares at his door. From down the hall: the SOUND of bare feet thumping on th hardwood floor, with the added CLICKING of long nails. Right up to Martin’s bedroom door. Martin grips his blanket like a Spartan’s shield. A tense beat. Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN

dialogues.text: Good. Who?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: “Diana.” This stops Rebecca in her tracks. She turns to face Marti Her whole body language has changed now. Her hands make f at her sides. Her jaw pulses.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: ...What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Her name is Diana. INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM POV ANGLE: Watching Rebecca and Martin through a crack in curtains. Is this Sophie watching? Rebecca bends slightly to speak in low tones with Martin.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I know what you’re going through. She did it to me after my dad left. She got off her meds and started talking to... someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca puts a hand on Martin’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I had bad dreams about Diana, but that’s all they are. Because she isn’t real. Okay? Martin's face goes from hopeful confidant to disappointed Suddenly he looks more exhausted than any eight-year-old should ever be. Head bowed:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If you say so. The door opens and Sophie steps out, in a bath robe.  23.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Becca? Is that you? Rebecca stands up and approaches Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Hey, mom. Sophie notes Rebecca’s clothing color choice.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Still in mourning?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I just like black. Sophie nods, conceding. She pulls Rebecca into a welcome

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s good to see you. It takes a moment for Rebecca to hug back. Didn’t expect

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: You, too. Martin moves past, into the house.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing home, little mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin doesn’t look back, he just marches for his bedroom Over his shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She’1l tell you.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: He hasn’t been sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Who can blame him. Paul was everything to us. (corrects) Nearly everything.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Are you seeing a therapist? Sophie deflects by idly tidying up. As she does:  24.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m not going to talk about my problems to some stranger. I’ve been through this before. You were there when Vic left me, you remember.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I remember. She looks around the room and spies a half-eaten lunch on coffee table. The TV plays, muted. For the first time, we get a better look at the room, wit the new curtains. It’s more of a cave now. Some boxes of clothes (Paul’s) s in a corner of the room, like a hoarder’s starter kit. Th lack of natural light, mixed with the multicolored ambien light, all makes for a depressing, if macabre feel.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long have you been off-roading it? Sophie’s poor-me vibe disappears in a breath. She bites b

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me? INT. MARTIN’S ROOM Martin gets a gym bag from his closet and begins to stuff various articles of clothing from his chest of drawers. The raised voices of Sophie and Rebecca can be heard thro the walls and down the hall as Martin packs.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: --and once again, I am here by myself, trying to do it all on my own without any help--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Help? Is that your code word for making someone listen to you complain about your life all day?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Listen here, Rebecca Ann--  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin crosses from his bedroom to the bathroom across th hall, hefting his gym bag with him.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Answer the question!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You’re not my doctor, you’re my daughter, why can’t you just be on my side for once-- Martin emerges with his toothbrush in one hand. He heads back for the living room, glancing into-- A HOME OFFICE, its door halfway open. Martin stops. Curious. This is a room that is typically closed to him. Down the hall, the fight continues.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How about you be on Martin’s side, have you thought about that? Martin slowly approaches the door, to peer inside... POV: A SHADOW on the wall moves. Something’s in there. Startled, Martin hurries for the living room. INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM Mother and daughter still go at it.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Are you seriously accusing me of being a bad mother? You of all people?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Can we talk about Martin without you jumping to that idea? Come on!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me for being upset that I have to raise him without his father. Look how you turned out. This cuts Rebecca deep. If she lets it fester, she’ll sta crying. Instead, she hardens up.  26.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I’m going to give you some time. And when you aren’t totally manic, you can call me. Until then, I’m not letting Martin stay here. (calling) Martin, pack your-- Martin steps in, tense, carrying his bag and backpack.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m ready. Sophie is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Martin. Honey. Come on now. Rebecca is now empowered again. Authoritative.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Let's go. Rebecca leads Martin out the front door. Sophie is hot on their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You two planned this! Didn’t you!

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Nobody planned anything, mom. Martin looks back at his mother with a gentle look of pur sympathy. On his way out:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’ll be back soon as I can. (halfway out the door) Take your vitamins after dinner! EXT. SOPHIE’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Rebecca hurries for Bret’s idling SUV with Martin in tow. Bret meets them at the passenger side--

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Get back in, we're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Where we going?  27.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: My place. Bret moves. No questions. At the front door, Sophie calls after Rebecca:

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You're just like your father! Already in the SUV, Rebecca turns her full anger toward h mother and starts cursing her, while Bret races to shut t passenger automatic window. It seals up at the last word-

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: You're just like a crazy b-- EXT. REBECCA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - EVENING Establishing. The sky threatens to rain. The clouds are t color of fresh bruises. INT. REBECCA’S BEDROOM - EVENING Rebecca opens the door for Martin, showing him in like a hop to a hotel suite.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Here we are. You can take the bed tonight. Just stash your stuff wherever. Martin steps in and looks wide-eyed at the posters on the walls. Like he’s on an alien planet. Rebecca watches Martin. Suddenly feels embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or if you prefer the couch... Martin puts his bag on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. This is fine.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I’m gonna order some dinner. She gently shuts her door, letting him alone. Martin unzips the gym bag and digs around through the clo inside. He finds what he’s after, and pulls it out--  28. A FLASHLIGHT. He checks the switch, then puts it on the nightstand. INT. REBECCA’S LIVING ROOM Bret pulls Rebecca around to speak to her quietly before gets to the kitchen phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Was this your idea?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Bringing the kid here.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: It’s not safe there.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: So. You call the lady at the school. That’s what CPS is for. Exactly this.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: He’s my brother.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: She’s his mother.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: So? Bret takes a beat. Watches her carefully.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Becks. Did you do this to help him, or to hurt her? Rebecca crosses her arms. Nostrils flaring. In a scary ev tone, she tells Bret:

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: You should go now. Bret deflates. He grabs his keys. Staying on Rebecca, all stern face and disappointment... The sound of the front door SHUTTING...  29. And Rebecca slumps, almost caving in on herself. She puts hand over her face and lets out a long breath. INT. REBECCA’S KITCHEN - NIGHT Dark. Then a light clicks on to reveal we’re inside the fridge and Rebecca has just opened the door, peering in.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Let me see what I can put together for you... She grabs some lunchmeat.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about a sandwich? In the dinette right off the kitchen, Martin sits at the table, in his pajamas. He nods. His hair is wild from a recent bath. Rebecca builds a sandwich for him at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know this is a little late for dinner. So. We’1l call it a snack. (then) Crust or no crust?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Crust is fine. (then) Can you make them triangles? Rebecca grins.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Oh, you take after your big sister. She brings the sandwich on a plate to the table and prese it to him. Martin takes a bite. Nods: He approves. Rebecca then notices a HAIRBRUSH on the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Mom usually brushes my hair.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Well. I’1l give it a try.  30. Rebecca works on taming Martin’s messy hair while he eats For a moment, the two are actually content as siblings. H feels nurtured, and she feels like a proper caregiver. Then, Martin puts down his sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Rebecca?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If mom is crazy, does it mean we’re a little crazy too? Rebecca pauses. Unsure how to answer that question. It eats at her conscience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bonfire crackles. A bonfire made of clothes, CDs, and other personal effect SOPHIE (younger, exhausted) stands at the fire with a box her feet. She wears a bath robe that she’s been living in the past week, judging by its condition. Next to her, a 10-year-old REBECCA. Big eyes. And scared way children get when a pillar of their life changes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG REBECCA
dialogues.text: Is that Daddy’s stuff?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Not anymore. He abandoned it all when he ran off with that little harlot from work. Sophie pulls another shirt out of the box. Holds it in fr of her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Smell this. You know what that is? (Rebecca sniffs) Dior. “Dune.” Your mother doesn’t wear Dior. Sophie tosses the shirt onto the fire. The flames consume hungrily, flaring up.  31.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG REBECCA
dialogues.text: ...What happens now?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Transformation. Sophie reaches into her robe’s pocket and pulls out a prescription pill bottle. Holds it up... ...and tosses it into the fire with the clothes. Mental alarm bells go off in Rebecca’s head.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG REBECCA
dialogues.text: Why'd you do that?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: That’s the old me. They were supposed to help me keep my life together. Look what happened. (a breath) Time to let the world know I’m ready for something new. She dumps the last of the box into the fire. It ROARS up.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You hear me? Bring me someone who won’t run away! From one angle, with Sophie in silhouette against the roa bonfire, her head raised to the sky, the scene could be mistaken as something much more... ritualistic. EXT. REBECCA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - NIGHT Dead of night. It’s raining. INT. REBECCA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Rebecca sleeps, spooning a set of covers partly turned ba She's made visible in four-second intervals by the bright neon light from the sign outside her window. A faint SCRATCHING SOUND somewhere in the room causes her stir in her sleep. She wakes. And she finds she’s alone in the bed. Rebecca sits up. Blinks. Looks around.  32.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Martin? The neon winks off to reveal A SILHOUETTE in the door. Sm Partly enveloped in shadow from the room beyond. The SCRATCHING comes from somewhere in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? The neon lights up the room in a green glow, revealing nothing in the hall... Then it goes out, and the SILHOUETTE is back. The SCRATCHING continues. Rebecca reaches over to turn on the bedside lamp-- click. nothing happens. Click-click. Nope.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need to flip the light switch by you. The outlet is... here. She gets out of bed. The neon light returns, illuminating doorway... No one is there. Rebecca frowns. Takes a step forward, cautious. Beat. The light goes out again... Revealing the SILHOUETTE still there. Rebecca’s breath catches.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (softly) Martin? The shadow RISES now, from its small, hunched over state, something taller than Rebecca by a foot. Rebecca backpedals, stumbles, hits the hardwood floor-- The silhouette takes a step into the room and something l toenails CLICK against the wood surface-- Rebecca is trapped, the bedroom door her only way out, adrenaline dumping into her system all at once-- Then the neon returns--  33. And the silhouette EVAPORATES when the light washes over and for a precious few seconds Rebecca is safe-- Which is when Rebecca scrambles to get back up and RUSH f the wall switch by the door-- Slapping it with her hand while she’s in the wash of ligh CLICK. The bedside lamp turns on. Rebecca is alone in the lit room. Suddenly out of breath, but alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca steps in -- the light is already on in here. She takes a hard look at herself in the mirror. Glances down at her arm with the old scars. She tucks her arm to her side, like she’s trying not to t about it. Something makes a small sound in the room with her, and i heartbeat she’s back to fight-or-flight mode. The shower curtain is drawn partway. Rebecca advances slowly. She relaxes when she sees: MARTIN, asleep in the dry bathtub basin, in his pajamas. He clutches his flashlight to his chest. He’s using a tow for a pillow. Rebecca sits down on the tub’s edge and watches Martin sl Her attention drifts back to the bathroom door; to the hallway beyond. Questioning what just happened. PRE-LAP the sound of a doorbell RING-- EXT. REBECCA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - MORNING The rain has stopped. The sun shines. A lone figure in a raincoat stands at Rebecca’s stoop.  34. INT. REBECCA’S LIVING ROOM - MORNING Rebecca opens the front door to reveal the figure is EMMA And she looks sternly at Rebecca.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Did you take Martin?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who is it? Emma pushes past Rebecca, into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You can’t do this.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Emma sits on the couch, Rebecca paces.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: She’s unstable. It’s not a safe environment for him. For anyone.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Getting dressed for school. Emma looks to the closed bedroom door, then speaks direct but in a slightly low voice to prevent Martin overhearing

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Think about what you want to do.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I did. I brought him here.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I’m not talking about some kneejerk reaction. He can’t stay here.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Sure he can.  35.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Not without-- Rebecca, come on. You know why I’m here? She called me.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: So Child Services takes orders from nutjobs now? She’s on triazolam and beta blockers for a reason. Emma stands up like she’s taking the pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I went there, I stopped by in person to make sure she was lucid, and she was, but you know what? That’s not how this works.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Sophie is his birth mother. His legal guardian. To get Martin from her custody requires you to file charges against her. Take her to court. That’s a long, painful process, and that’s only the first half. To keep Martin from being placed into foster care, you’d need to prove yourself and your home as an appropriate surrogate. (beat) So that’s two major choices for you to make: Declaring war on your mother, and transforming into a responsible guardian for him. Are you ready to do that? Rebecca blinks. She didn’t expect that truth slapped at h this early.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I can be a responsible guardian. Emma answers by looking past Rebecca, and then around the room, taking it all in. More HEAVY METAL POSTERS. Some with provocative illustrat women. A book on the coffee table about tattoo artists. A finally, a plastic bong on the bookshelf. Emma doesn’t say a word. She doesn’t have to.  36. EXT. REBECCA’S FRONT STOOP - MORNING Emma takes Martin by the hand to her car. Martin looks back at Rebecca who stands at her doorway. He waves at her.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I got some sleep. I’11 do better tonight. Rebecca waves and smiles wanly. But honestly, the little is breaking her heart. INT. REBECCA’S BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER Rebecca shuffles in, hand over her eyes. Her body languag screams, “What the hell am I doing.” She bends down to pick up a t-shirt of hers on the floor. When she does, she freezes. Her attention is riveted to something on the floor... A STICK FIGURE IN A DRESS has been carved into the hardwo flooring, with a name scrawled beneath it:

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Rebecca shudders. Crouches down and traces one of the let with her finger. It’s triggering some memory; her gaze wanders off the floor and up, as if she starts to see it the same room-- All the while darkness encroaches around her, until-- INT. REBECCA’S CHILDHOOD BEDROOM - NIGHT (FLASHBACK) A young REBECCA (age 10) sleeps in her bed. From somewher the room, a nightlight casts a wan glow over her. Then... with a brief BUZZ, the nightlight winks OUT. STAYING ON REBECCA who stirs in her sleep, some part of h aware that the light has changed. A door creaks open. Rustling sounds. Like a rat in a cupboard.  37. This wakes Rebecca. She blinks. Sits up. Her bedroom CLOSET DOORS hang open. Inside: pitch black. All is quiet. Then: the rustling continues. A bit clearer now: Paper is involved. Someone handling paper. Coming from the closet. Rebecca gets gooseflesh and her heart rate skyrockets. She reaches over to her nightstand to turn on her lamp-- But the lamp is GONE. A place for a lamp is there, even a footprint on the surface, but it’s not there now. Rebecca turns back to face the closet with renewed fear. There, at the base, on its side: the lamp. Nostrils flaring, Rebecca slips out of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG REBECCA
dialogues.text: Mom...? Is that you? Beat. The rustling pauses.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sweetheart. Rebecca frowns. Takes a tentative step for the closet.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG REBECCA
dialogues.text: What are you doing? No answer. Scratching on paper. Then:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Your mother is going to be fine. Rebecca takes two more steps. The closet interior is a black hole in the wall. WOMAN’S VOICE (CONT'D) I’m here now. Rebecca quickly reaches out and flicks on the closet ligh The closet LIGHTS UP to reveal-- NO ONE INSIDE, but something FALLS from midair--  38. An old sketch pad. And a black crayon. The crayon rolls to Rebecca’s bare foot. Rebecca looks around, utterly terrified there’s no one th THE SKETCH PAD lies open to an old drawing. A stick-figure trio. Mommy, Daddy, Me. Daddy has been crossed through. And in the same black cra a new figure has been added:

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Young Rebecca stares down in shock-- INT. REBECCA’S BEDROOM - BACK TO SCENE Present-day Rebecca stares down at the same handwriting carved into her floor. She grabs her phone. Still distracted by the carving, she brings up her voicemail. On speaker, she plays an old message.

dialogues.speaker: VOICEMAIL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Saved message. Thirty-two days old. BEEP. Then Paul’s voice:

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rebecca. This is your step-father. You know I wouldn't be calling if it weren't serious. I just... It involves your mother. Call me? BEEP. Rebecca never called. But she has a grim idea now-- INT. REBECCA’S KITCHEN - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Rebecca’s thumb on the power button to her weathered la as the boot sequence CHIMES. - Rebecca’s hand on the fridge, pulling a card for an LAP detective from the door. - Digits lighting up on her cell phone’s screen: “7-1-4” - Rebecca’s fingers flutter on the keyboard, that black n polish shining in the screen’s glow.  39.

dialogues.speaker: THEN
dialogues.text: Rebecca holds the phone in her hand at the little kitchen table, her laptop screen visible. On screen: An ARTICLE f LA Times: Store Owner Beaten to Death in Anaheim A PHOTO of Paul’s car in the garage accompanies the artic but it’s shot from the other side of where his body was found, so all we see are LAPD officers standing around an looking grim at the (unseen) body.

dialogues.speaker: DET. PETRUCCI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (faint; from phone) Yeah, Petrucci.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Detective Petrucci? This is Rebecca Lloyd. We spoke a few weeks ago, about my step-father’s murder? She paces the room as she listens. The Detective’s voice barely heard on the other line.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paul Wells, yes. Did you catch whoever did it? Rebecca scrolls down the article on her laptop and puts Petrucci on speakerphone while she keeps reading.

dialogues.speaker: DET. PETRUCCI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) --pursuing every lead, but what we need most now is some help from people who knew Paul. How well did you know him?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Me? I mean, not really.

dialogues.speaker: DET. PETRUCCI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Did you get along with him? Rebecca doesn’t like where this is going. Is she a suspec Now her attention is on her phone.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I guess? He was my step-dad. Why?  40.

dialogues.speaker: DET. PETRUCCI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Because you’re the first family member to call me since I was put on the case. Usually the wife is calling me every day, asking for updates. (beat) What happened with your mother’s first husband? Holy shit -- he’s not suspicious of her, he’s after Sophi

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Dad ran off with a client. That’s all. Over the speakerphone, she can hear Petrucci typing at hi computer, making notes.

dialogues.speaker: DET. PETRUCCI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Uh-huh, and you were Martin’s age when that happened, right? Would you say your mother suffers from mood swings? Suddenly this is a very charged call. Rebecca takes it of speaker and puts it to her ear --

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I gotta go. And she hangs up. For a moment her eyes wander, then she up, having committed to a course of action: Time to go straight to the source. PRE-LAP a DOORBELL: EXT. SOPHIE’S HOUSE - DAY Rebecca stands on the front porch just as a taxi pulls aw from the curb. She rings the bell again. Stands back and checks the driveway: No car.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: (calling out) Mom? You home? Nothing. Checking over her shoulder, Rebecca bends down --  41. And pulls a small plastic magnetized CONTAINER from under windowsill. Slides it open to reveal: A HOUSE KEY. INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Rebecca steps inside and shuts the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Hello? No response. Rebecca ventures deeper into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca ascends the stairs and heads for the master bedro She glances in at the home office on her way and stops in tracks. Turns. And steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul’s working space. Oak desk, home computer, filing cabinets. A small treadmill in the corner. That’s not the strange part. The weirdness is the fact that the framed photos have bee taken down. Paul’s diploma, his choice of landscape art.. Even the filing cabinets are partly gutted. Rebecca notices a corner of the room: A weird MAKESHIFT BED built from pillows and a quilt is tucked back behind one side of the desk, where the desk l has been unplugged, and the cord CHEWED OFF. Something new hangs on the wall here. It’s not the same dimensions as what used to hang on the hook; the paint on wall is discolored in a different shape. Rebecca leans in to look at the new framed photo: A black-and-white snapshot, at least thirty years old. Ev the frame suggests 1980s. It’s at a hospital, outside on the grounds. Slightly off center of the pic stands a WOMAN with her back to us, hea partly turned to look our way. The shade of a wild-shaped tree hides her face from us.  42. Rebecca looks around. Feeling like she’s being watched. Carefully, she takes the framed photo down from the wall. And slides the photograph out from under the glass. On the other side of the photo, some handwritten info in faded pen: “Diana / Mulberry Hill Rehab Hospital (1986)” Rebecca stares at the photo again with renewed tension. A the figure under that crooked tree could come to life. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE SOPHIE’S HOUSE - DAY Rebecca stands at the curb, still clutching the photo. Bret pulls up in his SUV and gets out. Approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Got your message. You wanna tell me what this is about?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I need a ride. To a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Come on-- She goes for the passenger door, but it’s locked.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s just go. I’1l tell you about it in the car. Bret isn’t caving. He crosses his arms at her.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Don’t you think we should finish talking about last night? You know, when you kicked me out for trying to be honest with you? Rebecca takes a moment to remember. It’s readable on her face, “Oh, right.” Bret’s a bit surprised. She doesn’t remember?  43.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: That. Yeah. Hey. She steps up to him. Looks him in the eyes. And kisses hi the mouth. She pulls back. Takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were right. I was using Martin to get back at mom. I’m sorry. Bret’s a little loopy from the kiss. But he recovers.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Well, you should apologize to Martin, really. I mean, uh-- not like you did with me, but...

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I need to do a lot of things. Starting with a visit to Mulberry Hill mental hospital. Bret heads back around to the driver's side--

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Diana was a patient there. (still amazed) The bitch is real! They both get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Who's Diana?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Let’s find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bret’s SUV pulls up to the curb. Bret and Rebecca get out They both stare at something 0.S., disturbed. Rebecca looks at the photo in her hands, then back up.

dialogues.speaker: ARM AROUND TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: The mental hospital building, set back from the street on wide, once-green lawn.  44. It’s the same structure, for sure. Some different paint h and there, stripped landscaping, in need of a pressure wa Oh, and the SIGN out front: “MULBERRY HILL APARTMENTS”

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Well. This is awkward. (beat) So, what now?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Someone’s gotta know. She heads for the front doors. Bret reluctantly follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHOTO is examined in a man’s meaty hand. This is the apartment manager, LOUIS. He scratches his ch

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: This place hasn’t been a medical center for over ten years. Looks like this was taken back in the nineties. Rebecca takes the photo back.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What happened to it? Louis shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Got shut down. Bankruptcy.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: What happened to all the patients?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: They lived happily ever after. How do I know? I just manage the place.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: You don’t have any forwarding info?  45.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: If I did, it’d be at least ten years old by now. Louis goes back to his fast food meal at his desk, talkin while he eats.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They got evicted. State law is three day’s notice. They left a lot of junk behind for the owners to clean up, tenants do that shit all the time.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What happened to that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Auctioned or thrown out. (slurps soda) All except for the patient files. Rebecca and Bret are on their way out the door when he sa that last line. They stop.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: They left patient files?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stained carpet. Flickering piss-yellow bulbs. This place would feel right at home in Fincher’s SE7EN. Louis leads them down the hall, keychain jangling.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I keep telling the owners to just burn this stuff, but everyone's afraid of lawsuits these days, so they have me keep it in 157. He goes to a door that’s been damaged recently. “157.” A fresh deadbolt LOCK has been installed. Rebecca notices

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: That looks new.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: We get break-ins around here. Welcome to the neighborhood. ‘Course, I don’t know what’s worth stealing in here, or who'd care.  46. He opens the door and turns on the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metal shelves and an old gurney serve as storage spaces f ROWS OF BOXES, some with lids, others open to the element It’s an auditor’s nightmare. And it smells of mildew.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: If someone’s files are in here, odds are the world stopped caring about ‘em long ago. Rebecca steps in and starts looking around. At the door, Bret stops Louis.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: You turned a creepy hospital into low-income housing? Seriously? Louis looks at Bret as if Bret still believes in Santa.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: It’s a building. (as he leaves) Tell her she can look but she can’t take anything home with her. Bret steps in to find Rebecca in the middle of the room. Surrounded by files.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: You hear that? Rebecca nods, but her mind is elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah. (sotto) Someone should've told my mom that. EXT. SOPHIE’S HOUSE - DAY A school bus pulls away from the curb as Martin walks to front door of the house. The heavy curtains are still drawn.  47. INT. SOPHIE’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Martin lets himself in. The house is quiet. The TV muted.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Mom? I’m home... Martin crosses to the bedroom hallway, turning lights on he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the home office, Sophie emerges, holding a small ham She approaches, happy to see him.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Welcome home. How was school? Martin regards her cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Okay. (then) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Just fixing up around the house. How did it go at your sister's?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Fine. Did you take your vitamins?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Well, I am feeling better. Listen, I've been a little... distant lately. And I want to fix that. How about pizza and a movie tonight? Martin brightens. Is old mom coming back?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, please. Sophie smiles, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Good. Some personal time is just what we need. Just the three of us. She moves past Martin for the stairs...  48. And at the other end of the hall, a SHADOW extends from t home office at the doorway. Someone standing just inside room, out of view. DIANA. Martin’s body seizes with tension. He keeps his eyes on t silhouette, but reaches over for a wall switch... And turns on the hall light. Diana is gone the instant the light comes on. An appariti Martin takes a tense breath.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (calls) Mom?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How about just you and me tonight? Sophie appears at the mouth of the hall. She and Martin m eye contact. She smiles politely.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We'll see. (then) She isn’t that bad, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca and Bret dig through files. They’ve been at it fo while. The place is messier, boxes opened, papers scatter

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: This is useless. All I got are patient numbers. No names.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: How does this photo of someone named Diana have anything to do with your family?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Because my mother went here, when she was about my age.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Well then, here’s a thought: Why don’t you call her and ask?  49.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I can’t. Not about this. (beat) Mom's always been a little... off. It’s just brain chemistry, not her fault. But after Dad left, she started talking to herself. Just whispers. Then, it became a full character. She called her Diana.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: And you think she’s based on another patient here. Rebecca puts her hands on her face, weary from the diggin around in other people's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I was really hoping. Bret opens another box. Does a double take.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Whoa. Mother lode. He pulls up a shoebox full of MICRO-CASSETTE TAPES. Pluck one from the pile. BRET (CONT’D) They're so tiny! I didn’t even know this was a thing.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: You didn’t know about micro- cassette recorders? Bret discovers a MCR/Player inside as well. Fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: I think I have batteries for this in my truck. He gets up and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: We can’t take the stuff out of here. So.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: ...Okay.  50. Bret steps out. Immediately Rebecca feels uneasy. She sta digging in the same box Bret was searching. She pulls out a slim POWER CORD. Tries one end on the jac for the MCR/Player-- It fits.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bret! Wait-- I found a cord! No answer. He’s already gone. Rebecca stares at the cassettes a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - She plugs the cord into a power outlet. - She snaps a cassette into the tiny recorder. - MACRO SHOT of the cassette heads spinning. - VOICES drone on from the player. - Rebecca EJECTS a tape, slaps in another. - The whole process is repeated. She’s searching... LATER: WHITE NOISE hisses like steady rain. The volume is cranked on the little speaker. Rebecca lets it play as she digs through file boxes. A pile of opened cassette cases lies next to the player.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Patient two-eighty-three, admitted October 3, 1984. Removed from the basement of her father’s home. She has a peculiar skin condition, worse than albinism. Never seen anything like it before. We’ve been testing her with-- (knocking) Bring her in. Shut off the-- okay. (beat) Hello, Diana. Rebecca stops her search. Looks at the recorder now. DIANA’S VOICE ..-Keep the lights out. Her voice is meek; ethereal. A little raspy. Rebecca stops the tape. Rewinds. Replays.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Patient two-eighty-three, admitted--  51. Paused again. Rebecca goes to another shelf. Every file box here is numbered. In the 200s. Rebecca’s finger drifts past box after box... 281, 282-- Boom. Box 283. Rebecca pulls it.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Rebecca digs through the box, sitting near the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello, Diana. DIANA’S VOICE Keep the lights out. Rebecca stares at the recorder now. She knows this voice.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: How long have you had this condition? Diana? The player hisses white noise. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did your father have it too? Or your mother? DIANA’S VOICE They aren’t my real parents. A pause. Rebecca leans closer.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Another patient in the heliotherapy ward says you visit her at night. The word rings a bell, and Rebecca thumbs through files u she finds a folder with the same tab: “HELIOTHERAPY.” In the folder, Rebecca finds PHOTOS of patients standing front of light boxes. Others in rooms with UV-lit walls. DIANA’S VOICE She is my friend. Annotations of disorders treated this way: Bipolar. Sleep phase disorder. Nervous breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Then why did you hurt her? Her arm is broken in three places.  52. An ARTICLE slips out of the folder, on aged newsprint: New ‘light therapy’ claims life of patient Diana Walter REBECCA’S EYES frantically skim the words on the piece -- “skin condition” -- “perhaps spontaneous combustion” -- “left nothing but a shadow on the wall” And the date: 1987. DIANA’S VOICE (small) She was getting better. When she gets better she goes away. Leaves. A shadow SLIDES OVER HER in a vague humanoid form, as if something were rising behind Rebecca in the small room-- Rebecca whirls around, on edge-- WIDE ANGLE: Nothing is there. She’s alone. DIANA’S VOICE (CONT’D) So I made her stay. EXT. SOPHIE’S HOUSE - DUSK The sun sets, with a sliver of a crescent moon higher in sky, among brooding clouds. INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM - DUSK The lights are on. But the curtains are drawn. Sophie and Martin share the couch with a bowl of popcorn between them, watching TV. Sophie wears a hat now, shield her eyes from the overhead light. Martin steals a glance at his mother. Noting the hat. Sophie gives him a sidelong glance in return. Then smiles

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: How are you doing over there?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Okay. (then) How are you?  53.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna be fine. I am. They watch TV some more. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I miss your father. He was strong for me. He protected me. I think I need to feel that, sometimes. And I know you need that, too. Martin’s expression suggests he clearly does. Yet:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m okay. (then) Rebecca is strong. Sophie makes a sarcastic noise through her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: She tries to look the part, all that makeup and loud music. But when it got tough she abandoned me. Don’t let her do the same to you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sometimes, the strongest thing to do, is to face your fears. That's what Emma told me. Beat. Sophie looks at Martin with newfound respect. Smile

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You know what, you’re right. (gets up) Be right back. Sophie crosses, leaving Martin on the couch. Martin grabs the remote and PAUSES the TV. The lights go OUT.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Mom! Sophie is back in a breath, before Martin can stand up-- She puts her hands on his shoulders. Firmly.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. It’s all right.  54. Martin goes from zero to sheer panic:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What are you doing--

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Look at me. Trust me. With her position between Martin and the TV, Sophie casts LONG, INK-DARK SHADOW over him that extends to the edge o the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Mom, let go--

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: A long time ago, I was friends with Diana. She was different. Special. From that shadow, SOMETHING MOVES. Sophie talks in a crazed reverence, one part nostalgia, o part Stockholm Syndrome.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After I left the hospital, I thought something... tragic happened to Diana. But the newspapers got it wrong, she was still here, and she finally visited me when I had a clear head again. Martin tries to look back, not sure if he wants to-- As the shadow EXTENDS, as if moving on its own-- No, not extending... GETTING CLOSER.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Mom please no, please please--

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Took me another ten years to realize why she left. It was the i It blocked her out, left her all alone. And you know what? She's tired of being alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin struggles, but Sophie remains firm. DIANA’S SHADOW now looms over him... A clawed HAND touchi his hair...  55.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have been a terrible friend to her, but now she’s going to stay. Long as I keep my head clear... and you keep the lights out. MARTIN'S HAND digs into the seat cushion, searching-- Just as JET BLACK HAIR descends by Martin's face, like th shadow is starting to LEAN OVER AT HIM-- MARTIN'S HAND finds its target and lifts out a small, aluminum FLASHLIGHT-- Which he flicks on straight up, under-lighting his face--

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No! Something SHRIEKS. SOPHIE IS THROWN BACK, spilling over the coffee table. Martin stands on the couch, holding the flashlight over h like a spot in a darkened theater. His heart is racing like a marathon runner. Eyes wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whipping around the room, in search of Diana.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Martin, what did you do?! Martin races to the wall switch and turns on the lights. Sophie blinks at the sudden light. Like an alcoholic step out from a dive bar in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t make this harder than it has to be, please -- But Martin is too terrified to talk to her now. He runs t the front door, swings it open, and flees outside. INT. BRET’S SUV - NIGHT Bret drives. Rebecca rides shotgun. She places earbuds in ears. The thin cord snakes down to the microcassette play Bret glances over at her. Does a double take.  56.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: The dude said not to take anything.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Like he’s gonna know what’s missing. Rebecca presses ‘play’ and stares out her window, listeni to one of the tapes.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Is that another session with Diana? Rebecca doesn’t look back at Bret. She watches the city lights drift by her window, thumb on the player.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: No... This one is my mother. She turns up the volume and starts to tune out the rest o the world. SLOW PUSH as she listens to the tape. We don’t hear the recording, beyond the dull mono-channel pitch of that doctor’s VOICE in her ears... CLOSING IN on Rebecca, closing her eyes... THE SCORE builds as the sound of that doctor’s voice gets little clearer... Can start to make out some of it --

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sophie, you need to be careful around Diana. She isn’t your friend.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SOPHIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes she is. She may be my only friend in here. TIGHTER ON REBECCA as we can make out --

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SOPHIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That’s all she wants -- When Bret’s HAND enters frame, touching Rebecca:

dialogues.speaker: BRET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey -- INT. BRET’S SUV - NIGHT Rebecca snaps open her eyes -- Bret is nudging her.  57. She stops the player and pulls out the earbuds.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: You have a visitor. He nods at something on her side of the road. They've parked out front of her apartment building. And MARTIN is standing on her front stoop. A nervous wrec

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Oh, no... INT. REBECCA’S KITCHEN - NIGHT Bret searches the fridge, closes the door in defeat.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: You need to go shopping, girl. Rebecca and Martin are seated at her little dining table. Martin has hold of Rebecca’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Can you run down to the little mart on the corner?

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Yeah. I‘ll get some snacks, maybe a couple sodas --

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: No caffeine.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Copy that. As Bret breezes by, he pats Martin on the shoulder. A mom later, he’s out the door... Leaving Martin with his sister.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: You wanna talk about it now?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I know you don’t believe me, but Diana is real. She touched my hair.  Rebecca

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS
dialogues.text: Rebecca between 58.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. Look at me. (then) I believe you. She’s real. I don’t know how or why...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She doesn’t like the light. lets out a long breath. Nods. Then stands up --

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: places printouts of web resources on the table her and Martin. Wikipedia. WebMD.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Here’s what I know: In 1986, mom hit a low point with her depression and was admitted to a hospital for treatment. Her kind of depression is best fought with heliotherapy. (off the boy’s look) That’s using sunlight, or a special kind of artificial light, exposure to it for long stretches.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’ve only seen her take pills.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: That works, too. So, when she was in the hospital, she made friends with another patient -- an extreme case. Her name was Diana. This gets Martin’s full attention.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She’s like Mom?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: No. Mom got better and was released, but Diana reacted to the treatment so badly she died.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So, if Diana is dead, I mean... How can she be doing this to us?  59.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Every time our mom falls off the wagon and lets depression back in, Diana shows up. Like a schism, or, I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How did you get rid of Diana the first time?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I didn’t. Mom took a spill down the stairs one night, spent a month in the hospital where they put her back on her meds, and-- (ding ding ding) That’s what we do. We get her back on the wagon, Diana will go away.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Diana wants to stay. She won’t like you trying to make mom better.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That's what my dad was doing. At that moment, a KNOCKING from the front door. Insistent

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: That’s Bret, hang on. Rebecca goes to her door, opens it --

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I left it unlocked, silly -- But no one’s there. Rebecca looks left, right -- nothing. An even LOUDER KNOCKING happens from the coat closet, cau Rebecca to jump. She shuts the front door and cautiously approaches the co closet. Reaches for the door knob.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bret...?

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Martin watches; starts to tense up. He retreats a couple steps, for Rebecca’s bedroom.  60.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Gets close to the door... she can hear something on the o side. A raspy breath. Sub-vocal muttering. Flicks on the light beside the coat closet door. The yellow light seeps through the door’s cracks. And in that moment, all the noises inside STOP. INT. REBECCA’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS Martin turns on the light and backs from the bedroom door All is quiet, then -- the bedroom closet door BANGS from someone KNOCKING on it inside. Martin freaks out.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSING IN ON THE DOOR --
dialogues.text: Hearing that muttering now but more pronounced: DIANA’S VOICE Never-going-away-never-going-away never-going-away-never-going-away-- Rebecca rushes in, flips on the bedroom closet light, and swings open the door and -- No one’s there. It’s empty. Rebecca and Martin stare at the clothes on hangars, swayi as if someone had just brushed past... Pre-lap the sound of a DOORBELL -- EXT. SOPHIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Sophie opens the door and peers out at: Rebecca, Martin, and Bret.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Mom... We need to talk. INT. SOPHIE’S DINING ROOM - NIGHT Sophie, Martin, Rebecca, and Bret all sit at the dining table. You could hear a pin drop.  61. The awkward silence lasts a long beat as everyone keeps glancing around at everyone else. It’s the Cold War. Rebecca finally speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Mom... Tell us about Diana. Sophie puts down her glass of water. Suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Martin and Rebecca glance at each other: What's she doing Bret takes a bite from a corner-store snack. Trying to fi out how to be supportive at a time like this.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Your “friend” Diana? Martin says she was just here an hour ago? Sophie looks from Martin to Rebecca with a guarded expression. Holds up her hand to shield her eyes from the dining room lights. Her looks even paler, now.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yes, she’s my friend... And she wants to be yours, too. Rebecca puts the PHOTO onto the table. The one she took f Sophie’s office.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: This the same Diana you’re friends with now? Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Answer my question--

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Answer mine!

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: You met her at Mulberry Hill when you got put in for depression, right? Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What does it matter when we met?  62.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Because she died a year later!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: That's a lie. Listen to yourself--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: That’s the truth-- Sophie stands up, her chair SCREECHING on the floor. In f “defensive peacock” mode.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What is this about? You trying to take my son away again, is that it? With your made-up stories-- Bret attempts to intervene--

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa, let’s all be cool-- But now voices are overlapping, everyone trying to get in

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I found the obituary! All right?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Like those can’t be faked, listen to yourself, you sound crazy--

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: This whole thing’s a little crazy-- Rebecca looks down at the table, aware it’s come to this:

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: There’s a dead woman in this house. Everyone hears her. And it quiets the whole room. Rebecca looks up at her mother, accusing--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you let her in, mom. You let her stay. Every time. Beat. The tension: through the roof. Everyone staring at other like it’s a Mexican standoff. Then... Sophie chuckles. A small laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I am so sorry. All this time I was worried about the wrong thing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (a breath) You’re not here to take Martin. You aren’t coming back into our lives. You're here to feel better about leaving me. Do you know how I felt, not hearing from you or seeing you like family should? You know how that hurt me? Well, turns out I’ve been shutting out Diana the same way, all this time, and I won't be that kind of person to a friend.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Mom. She’s not a friend. She's dead. Sophie leans in. Looks right at her.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Sweetie... Ghosts aren’t real. Sophie turns and walks out, up the stairs. Martin stares at the pills on the table. Scared.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Then what is she? From the back of the house, they all hear Sophie’s bedroo door slamming SHUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca, Bret and Martin clean dishes and toss trash.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: You can sleep over at my place again tonight. I’1l talk to CPS about this.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What do you mean ‘no’?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I know you've been gone a long time, but she’s our mom. And she needs us now, more than ever.  64.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I’m not here for her, I’m here for you. That’s the priority. Beat. Martin takes a dish and moves it to the drying rack turning his back on Rebecca. This little boy has grown up heartbreakingly fast.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I can’t just leave her. Rebecca notices.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: It isn’t safe here. Martin turns around to face her.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It isn’t safe anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: All right. Here’s what we’ll do. Bret and I will stay over tonight. Tomorrow, I’1l find some more history on Diana and show it to Emma. Make the case that this is a serious threat. Maybe we can get mom some real help that way. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Okay. INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT The place looks like someone has been a shut-in for a mon Messy. Those boxes of Paul’s clothes and other sundries a still stacked. A few other eye sores. Rebecca surveys the room, arms akimbo. Bret and Martin st at her side.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: How long does she stay in her room at night?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Mom? She won’t usually come out again until morning.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Okay. First priority, make this more of a home.  65.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: The trio clean the room. - Rebecca pulls the heavy curtains back and ties them. - Martin wipes down surfaces. - Bret carries boxes to the garage.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Next, we put in some safeguards. - Rebecca duct-tapes a light panel in the “on” position. - Martin tests a flashlight and sets it on an end table. - Bret places a heavy piece of furniture up against a pow cord plugged into an outlet.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The important thing is to just be smart about it. - Rebecca sets an extra box of LIGHT BULBS on a counter. - Martin places another flashlight in a hallway potted pl Like it’s a handgun or a piece of contraband. - Bret sets his cigarette lighter next to a large candle. INT. MARTIN’S ROOM - NIGHT Martin climbs into bed. Rebecca watches from the door.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Bret and I will be downstairs on the sleeper sofa. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Door open or closed?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Closed. (then) Wait-- Rebecca pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you sleep in here instead? Beat. Rebecca was obviously looking forward to her boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca walks past the door to the home office She checks the door out of curiosity. Locked. Rebecca frowns. Moves on. INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Bret fluffs an old pillow on the fold-out sofa do with blankets from the downstairs closet. Rebecca arrives and admires Bret for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: You don’t have to stay, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Martin wants me to sleep in his room tonight. Bret takes a breath. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Yeah. He needs you more than I do right now.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: You still staying?

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Unless you say otherwise. Yeah. Although it’s gonna be weird trying to sleep with all the lights on-- Rebecca pulls him into a hug.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Bret is a bit surprised by her intimacy. 66. being close to -- shut. bed. He’s made  67.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: You can be like this around me, you know. I’m not going anywhere. Rebecca looks at him curiously. Like she’s weighing a decision. Then:

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Bottom drawer of my dresser.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: ...What?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: It’s yours. I'll clear it out for you.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Seriously? She smiles and heads back up. Bret waits until she’s out of sight, then does a silent “touchdown celebration” move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca returns to Martin’s room, but then continues to t end of the hall, to the master bedroom door. Sophie’s doo It’s shut. Rebecca gets close. Listens. Knocks.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Mom? We're staying overnight. (beat; silence) See you in the morning. (another beat) Love you. Rebecca pulls away. The door opens a crack. Sophie peers out at her daughter. Her eyes are bloodshot her face is wet from crying.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You're staying?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Sophie nods, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Good. (then) I'd like to maybe start over, in the morning. Would... would you grant me that? Beat. Rebecca is cautious. But hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Shake on it. She opens the door further to reach out her hand. The interior of the bedroom is PITCH DARK. Rebecca shakes hands with her mother. 68. As she does, she frowns; something is amiss, but we don’t know what she’s reacting to. They pull away.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Goodnight, mom.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Becks. The pajama top Sophie wears starts to PULL as if someone tugging it from behind, coaxing her back in. Rebecca doesn’t see it. She’s distracted... As she gets to Martin’s bedroom, she looks down. IN HER HAND is a slip of paper, handed to her by Sophie. She unfolds it to read: “I NEED HELP.” Written hastily. Rebecca looks back down the hall. Worried. Because she’s starting to think of mom not as an opponent but as a victim.  69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca turns on the light and immediately goes to the medicine cabinet. Flings it open, digs around the shelves checking bottles, getting more and more frustrated--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: C'mon, c’mon... Finally she exhausts the selection of OTC and prescriptio bottles in the cabinet and looks around the bathroom in desperation. Her attention is drawn to the small trash bin, by the toi Rebecca reaches in and pulls out a narrow pill bottle. Em She reads the prescription on the side, and--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sotto) Shit... The bottle is missing its white lid. Overhead, the bathroom light begins to FLICKER and BUZZ. Rebecca keeps the pill bottle and backs out of the room, suddenly nervous, as if she were being watched. INT. MARTIN’S ROOM - NIGHT Rebecca joins Martin under the covers. Puts a hand on Martin’s shoulder so he knows she’s there. The bedside lamp is on, plus two large candles on the nightstands on either side of the bed. She closes her eyes. Martin is still awake.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (beat) Rebecca?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Did you find her vitamins?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: No. But we’ll figure something out.  70.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You think so? Rebecca opens her eyes. Stares at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Heliotherapy works, too. We’ll get her out in the sun tomorrow. Go to the beach, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That sounds nice...

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: (softer) Get some sleep. He closes his eyes, but she lingers on that last question PRESSING IN on Rebecca, as she drifts to sleep... INT. MARTIN’S ROOM - NIGHT Only a night-light on the far wall sheds light in the roo now. And the decor is different; girly. Dolls and pink. In the bed is YOUNG REBECCA, maybe eight years old, huddl under the covers. She’s been crying. She stares at: A PHOTO of her father VICTOR standing with her, holding a pair of fishing rods. Father and daughter out playing. CLOSE ON REBECCA, breaking out of her memory when she hea the CLICKING OF TOENAILS on the hardwood floor. She holds her breath. Terrified. The mattress sinks under the weight of something new. PUSHING IN CLOSER on Rebecca’s face, as... Black HAIR descends near Rebecca’s ear -- that’s all we s of Diana, but then: DIANA’S VOICE Be my friend... It’s a gravelly version of the voice we heard on the micr cassette recording. Young Rebecca is too scared to scream. As if in a nightma  71. And with that, Diana starts to CRAWL INTO BED WITH REBECC pulling the covers on the far side of the bed. Rebecca closes her eyes even tighter than before and open her mouth to scream -- INT. MARTIN’S ROOM - NIGHT And Rebecca wakes with a start. Sits up. It was just a nightmare. Or a memory. Before it was Marti room it was hers, and she’s back again. Martin sleeps soundly next to her. Rebecca calms down. Somewhere in the bowels of the house -- a distant CLAP. And immediately after, the power goes out. Only the two candles burn in Martin’s room.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: (sotto) Shit... Rebecca grabs a commercial-grade flashlight from her side the bed, clicks it on, and slips out. INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Rebecca descends the stairs and enters the room, saying i stage-whisper:

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Bret! Wake up-- She sweeps the light over the sofa-bed... Bret isn’t there.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sotto) Shit. Shit shit shit. She moves for the downstairs hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the utter darkness, a door opens and Rebecca stands silhouette at the threshold.  72. She shines the beam downstairs. The steps are more like a ladder; steep. More boxes on the floor and on metal shelving down here. furniture. Seasonal junk for the lawn... And, on a load-bearing post: the house’s CIRCUIT BREAKER Rebecca descends the precarious steps. She advances for the box. As she does, shadows seem to bounce around the room. It m her paranoid. She keeps glancing behind her. At the box, she pries open the lid and shines the light a the breaker switches. They all seem to be in the proper position.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: C'mon, c’mon... She begins flipping switches back and forth. She glances back at the door for signs of power-- And a SILHOUETTE now stands in the threshold. Rebecca nearly screams, but recovers quickly enough to sw the flashlight beam at it-- Revealing it’s MARTIN with a candle in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: The power went out. I’m trying to restart it-- Martin sets the candle on the top step in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Keep the light on me--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Martin descends and hurries to her side.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Don’t leave me alone again.  73.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: (terse) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: (softens ) All right. She returns to the circuit breaker switches.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing is working.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What else could it be? Rebecca thinks. Something sinister occurs to her...

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: ...A trap. The soft sound of a short, quick breath comes from upstai And Martin’s CANDLE SNUFFS OUT. Rebecca looks up that way-- DIANA’S SILHOUETTE stands at the basement door. Rebecca grabs the flashlight and wheels it around but-- The door SLAMS shut and locks from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No-- NO. She hurries up the steps. Martin begins to fall into darkness, since she’s taking t flashlight with her--

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Wait up-- He hurries to keep up with her. The two reach the top step and try the door. No go. Rebecca shoulders against it. Won't budge. Partly because has to be on the steps, and can’t get much leverage or ro to charge the door.  74.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Come on! (bangs on door)

dialogues.speaker: HEY. SOMEONE
dialogues.text: EXT. SOPHIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Bret stands on the front lawn with his own flashlight, looking down the street. The whole block is out. Bret curses under his breath. INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Bret enters from the front door and immediately hears dul THUMPING from down the hall. He stops in his tracks. He then hears Rebecca’s muted CRIES-- And he kicks back into gear again.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Becca?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bret advances for the hall, shining his light down ahead him rather carelessly. He sees the basement door (built much like a door to a garage) rattling in its frame as Rebecca pounds on it fro the other side.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: Becca is that you?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bret! Get us out!

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: What are-- okay hang on-- Bret reaches for the doorknob to try it-- But then something distracts him down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca and Martin get quiet.  75.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Bret?

dialogues.speaker: BRET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hang on. (beat) Mrs. Wells?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bret squints down the hall at: DIANA’S SILHOUETTE. Statuesque. That same wild, ratty hai As tall as he is.

dialogues.speaker: BRET
dialogues.text: What’s going on here? He points his flashlight down the hall-- And like a mirage, Diana VANISHES soon as the beam hits t space where we saw her. Bret frowns.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muted) Bret! Listen to me! Keep in the light! Bret lowers the beam... And Diana’s shadow IS CLOSER. Halfway to him now. Bret jumps out of his skin, and pulls the flashlight back shine down the hall-- And she’s gone again. REBECCA (0.S.) (CONT’D) Don’t have just one-- she’ll get around you! Panicked, Bret swings around, checking behind him, toward front of the house-- No one there. He swings back-- The hall is empty. He holds the flashlight up high--  76. Swings down hard on the knob. CLANNNG. He holds it up again-- And something GRABS HIS ARM, yanking him out of frame-- INT. SOPHIE’S LIVING ROOM --hurtling him to the floor of the living room as if he w a child’s toy. THE FLASHLIGHT lands on the hallway floor, its light guttering like a candle about to be snuffed. The flashes the hallway a “strobe” effect. Bret has wrenched his shoulder but he starts to get up-- And then he sees her. The SILHOUETTE advances for him in fits of speed, backlit the sputtering flashlight in the hall-- Bret scrambles and pulls up his CELL PHONE pointing the screen out and shining it in front of him, like a talisma Diana is gone again.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muffled) Bret! Bret is hyperventilating as he stands. Scared out of his mind. It doesn’t make sense to him. The phone’s paltry ambient screen-light barely illuminate four feet in front of him. And it’s the passcode screen. Bret hears footfall on the floor-- To his left-- But he can’t see that far into the living room. Then to his right-- Still nothing. Then he hears it: raspy BREATHING. Like it’s right there.
